title: What's wrong with making America great again if everyone benefits from it? - Quora
tags: Politics of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Before we can answer that, we have to define what a great America is. Most people that I’ve seen describe it are looking back at the 1950s, specifically the fact that we were an economic power house. Some like the fact that we were a mostly unchallenged superpower, but I won’t go into that. Well, others have shown that the 1950s weren’t as perfect on the social level. I’m not even going to touch on that, I’d rather focus on the economic side. I’m sure you’re familiar with the basic events of World War II. Well, every country involved was running their industry at its maximum capacity, since that’s what you do in a war. Doing any less means it’s more likely you might lose. At any rate, the war didn’t last forever, it eventually came to an end. And most countries turned their industry to recovering from the war. First they had to rebuild the industry, since that was one of the targets of the war. Then they had to rebuild their infrastructure and society in general. There was one notable exception to this. You see, the US as a nation and as an economy was unique in that it never really took much damage during the war, so we weren’t in need of rebuilding. So while everyone else is dealing with rebuilding the necessities of life, the US was in a position to turn this massive industry towards making the US a consumer paradise. And when we did, we started selling it to anyone that would buy it. Because of this, the US dollar became the closest thing to an international currency in existence. By the time everyone else finished repairing the damage from the war, we had a massive head start on flooding world markets with our products and establishing ourselves as an economic powerhouse. Over time, the advantage of our head start started to fade. Our economy just didn’t shine quite like it did when we had no real competition, and it eventually “sunk” to where it is now. Which isn’t as bad as some people think, by the way. Yes, we have a trade deficit on hard goods. The trade deficit disappears as soon as you consider soft goods and services. Yes, even with China. You see, one of the things that happened when we started getting competition for our hard goods is our economy shifted towards soft goods and services. We’re no longer a primarily industrial economy, but rather an information and services economy. So, with all that in mind, what would it take to return us to the economy we had in the 1950s? Step one, we need another world war, one that devastates every major industrial base but ours. Second, we need to involve ourselves in said war, in such a way that it energizes our industrial base. Third, we need to shift away from an economy based on information and services and go back to an industrial based economy. Yeah, I’m gonna say no to every step of that, with the possible exception of involvement in WWIII, assuming it started for some other reason. It would be offensively self centered to hope for a war just so that we gain economic benefit. And really, shifting back to an industrial based economy might be better for those that think they want to work in a factory, but would really just be waiting outside hoping that enough of the robots break down so that the company would need to hire more humans. If you want to repair the US economy so that the middle class isn’t feeling left out, you need to deal with the disparity in income distribution. I’m not saying we need to take away all the rich people’s money and split it up evenly between everyone, but really, the disparity has been growing since the late 70s or early 80s, which is also when the middle class started feeling like there was something wrong. Henry Ford, when he started building cars, paid the workers on the assembly lines above average wages. Why? Because he knew that the better off the middle class was, the more money they’d have to spend on the products the wealthy are trying to sell them. That’s something that the US forgot somewhere along the way, and the middle class has been getting the shaft ever since.

It was a brilliant campaign slogan and one that resonated with ALL of us. Its power, however, comes not from truth but from nostalgia, the longing for a bygone past. The problem with nostalgia, and the slogan, is that it ignores many things about the past that were not “grreat.” The 1950s, which is usually the period people talk about as “great,” had many many problems. My mother was a brilliant woman. She wanted to be an architect. Women did not become architects in the 1950s. Women could work only as nurses, secretaries or, like my mother, as teachers. Until 1965, blacks could not vote in most of the South and had huge barriers on the job. ( saw a minstrel show at my junior high in 1960, white teachers in blackface strumming banjos.) Pollution was horrible — I remember literally choking on air in LA. Taxes, by the way, were much higher than they are now, up to 70 percent for the highest rate. True, crime was lower, jobs were plenty, things were simpler — on the surface. So there is an appeal to making America “great again” but in many ways America has become greater since the Fifites. More opportunity for women and people of color. Cleaner air and water. Lower taxes. Lowering crime (since 1990). Those who oppose the president also support greatness and love America but we cannot for the life of us see how a sniping and mean-spirited president, rolling back environmental laws, offending our allies, comforting dictators, and insulting everyone who disagrees with him is making America great in any way.
